div.head: Act 1, Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter King Frederick, Sorano, Valerio, Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, and Attendants.

lg.l: Will your Grace speak?
Let me alone, Sorano,

Although my thoughts seem sad, they
are welcome to me.

You know I am private as your
secret wishes,
Ready to fling my soul upon your service,
Ere your command be on't.
Bid those depart.
You must retire, my Lords.
What new design is hammering in his head now?
Let's pray heartily
None of our heads meet with it, my wife's old,
That's all my comfort.
Mine's ugly, that I am sure of,
And I think honestchaste; virginal OED honest adj.3b too, 'twould make me start else.
Mine's troubled in the country with a fever,
And some few infirmities else; he looks againe.,
Come, let's retire. Certain 'tis some she business,
This new Lord is employed.
I'll not be far off, because I doubt the cause.
lg.stage: Exit Valerio, Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, and Attendants.

lg.l: Are they all gone?
All but your faithful servant.
I would tell thee,
But 'tis a thing thou cannot like.
Pray ye speak it—is it my head? I have it ready for
ye, Sir.
Is't any action in my power? My wit?
I care not of what nature, nor what follows.
I am in love.
That's the least thing of a thousand,
The easiest to achieve.
But with whom, Sorano?
With whom you please, you must not be denied, Sir.
Say it be with one of thy kinswomen.
Say withal,
I shall more love your Grace, I shall more honor ye,
And would I had enough to serve your pleasure.
Why 'tis thy sister then, the fair Evanthe,
I'll be plain with thee.
I'll be as plain with you, Sir,
She brought not her perfections to the world,
To lock them in a case, or hang 'em by her,
The use is all she breeds 'em for, she is yours, Sir.
Do thou mean seriously?
I mean my sister,
And if I had a dozen more, they were all yours.
Some aunts I have, they have been handsome women.
My mother's dead indeed, and some few cousins
That are now shooting upgrowing quicklyOED shoot v.8a, we shall see shortly.
No, 'tis Evanthe.
I have sent my man after her
Upon some business to come presently.
Hither, she shall come. Your Grace dare speak to her?
Large golden promises and sweet language, Sir.
You know what they work; she is a complete courtier.
Besides, I'll set in.
She waits upon my Queen;
What jealousy and anger may arise,
Incensing her?
You have a good sweet lady,
A woman of so even and still a temper,
She knows not anger. Say she were a fury,
I had thought you had been absolute the great King,
The fountain of all honors, plays, and pleasures,
Your will and your commands unbounded also.
Go get a pair of beads and learn to pray, Sir.
My Lord, your servant stays.
Bid him come hither, and bring the lady with him.
I will woo her,
And either lose my self, or win her favor.
She is coming in.
Thy eyes shoot through the door,
They are so piercing, that the beams they dart
Give new light to the room.
Whether do thou go?
This is the King's side, and his private lodgings.
What business have I here?
My lord sent for you.
His lodgings are below, you are mistaken,
We left them at the stair-footbottom of the stairsOED stair-foot n.1a.
Good sweet Madam.
I am no Councilor, nor important suitor.
Nor have no private business through these chambers,
To seek him this way, o' my life thou art drunk.
Or worse than drunk, hired to convey me hither
Thou hast a bawdy face, and I abhor thee,
A beastly bawdy face, I'll go no further.
No, shrink not back, indeed you shall good sister.
Why do you blush? The good King will not hurt ye,
He honors ye, and loves ye.
Is this the business?

Yes, and the best you ever will arrive at, if you
be wise.
My Father was no bawdgo-between; pimpOED bawd n.1, Sir,
Nor of that worshipful stock as I remember.
You are a fool.
You are that I shame to tell ye.
Gentle Evanthe.
The gracious Queen, Sir,
Is well and merry, heaven be thanked for it,
And as I think she awaits you in the garden.
Let her wait there, I talk not of her garden,
I talk of her sweet flower.
Your Grace is pleasant
To mistake a nettleplant with green flowers and stinging hairsOED nettle n.1a for a rose.
No rose, nor lily, nor no glorious hyacinth
Are of that sweetness, whiteness, tenderness,
Softness, and satisfying blessedness
As my Evanthe.
Your Grace speaks very feelingly;

I would not be a handsome wenchWhile “wench” is a clearly gendered term (referring almost exclusively to females), it has many different meanings, all of which are applicable in this context. In a more neutral sense, a wench might describe a “girl, maid, young woman” or a “girl of the rustic or working class.”OED wench n.1a, 1b It is likely that Frederick employs wench as a term of endearment here, as he is courting Evanthe–a wench could be used in reference to a “sweetheart.”OED wench n.1c The last possible meaning of wench is a “wanton woman; a mistress,”OED wench n.2 which is also quite applicable here. Frederick follows this up by telling Evanthe “Thou shalt be any thing,” objectifying her in a multi-dimensional way that perhaps encompasses the different definitions of “wench.” Evanthe is not yet a wanton woman, but Frederick desires her in that manner and persistently attempts to court her into being his mistress. in your way, Sir,
For a new gown.
Thou art all handsomeness;
Nature will be ashamed to frame another.
Now thou art made, thou hast robbed her of her cunningartfulnessOED cunning n.5a.
Each several part about thee is a beauty.
Do you hear this, sister?
Yes, unworthy brother, but all this will not do.
But love Evanthe,
Thou shalt have more than words, wealth, ease, and honors,
My tender wench.
Be tender of my credit,
And I shall love you, Sir, and I shall honor ye.
I love thee to enjoy thee, my Evanthe,
To give thee the content of love.
Hold, hold, Sir, you are too fleet.
I have some business this way, your Grace can nere content.
You stubborn toy.
Good my Lord Bawd I thank ye.
Thou shalt not go, believe me, sweet Evanthe,
So high I will advance thee for this favor,
So rich and potent I will raise thy fortune
And thy friends mighty.
Good your Grace, be patient,
I shall make the most honorable wench that ever was.
Shame your discretion and your choice.
Thou shalt not.
Shall I be rich, do you say? And glorious?
And shine above the rest? And scorn all beauties?
And mighty in command?
Thou shalt be any thing.
Let me be honest too, and then I'll thank ye.
Have you not such a title to bestow too?
If I prove otherwise, I would know but this, Sir:
Can all the power you have, or all the riches,
But tie men's tongues up from discoursing of me,

Their eyes from gazing at my glorious folly,While a brief gloss of “folly” within this context might lend itself to “lewdness” or “wantonness”–OED folly n.3aespecially given Evanthe’s concern for her reputation if she acquiesces to Frederick’s relentless courting—the sixteenth-century Praise of Folly by Desiderus Erasmus (1511) opens up our understanding of the term. The personified Folly is a female character who speaks on her own behalf in a sort of defense tract throughout the text, which is supposedly composed during “a little time off for play,” but “leads to something slightly more serious” and perhaps educational (Author’s Preface 4-5). Folly is quite the spectacle throughout her extended self-praise; Evanthe would assume a similar role of public exhibition if she were to submit to her own feminine folly in this moment. The ending of The Praise of Folly is quite noteworthy, as Folly undermines herself and her reliability as a rhetor—addressing her male audience, she muses: “If you think I’ve been too cheeky or long-winded, remember you’ve been listening to Folly and a woman” (87). Like Folly, Evanthe is very aware of the societal constraints of her gender; while both women exemplify strong female characteristics, they also both undermine themselves. Although Evanthe turns down Frederick’s advances, she does so partially out of concern for her reputation as a woman, as opposed to entirely out of her own agency (or at least that is the image she is projecting here).Desiderus Erasmus, The Praise of Folly (1511).
Time that shall come from wondering at my impudence,
And they that read my wanton life from curses?
Can you do this? Have ye this magic in ye?
This is not in your power, though you be a prince, Sir,
No more than evil is in holy angels.
Nor I (I hope) get wantonnesse confirmed
By act of Parliament and honesty,
And so received by all, I'll hearken to ye.
Heaven guide your Grace.
Evanthe, stay a little,
I'll no more wantonness, I'll marry thee.
What shall the Queen do?
I'll be divorced from her.
Can you tell why? What has she done against ye?
Has she contrived a treason 'gainst your person?
Abus'dcuckholded; cheated onShakespeare, Merry Wives of Windsor, Act II, Scene 2 your bed? Does disobedience urge ye?
That's all one, 'tis my will.
'Tis a most wicked one,
A most absurd one, and will show a monster.
I had rather be a whore, and with less sin,
To your present lust, than queen to your injustice.
Yours is no love, faith and religion fly it,
Nor has no taste of fair affection in it,
Some hellish flame abuses your fair body,
And hellish furies blow it. Look behind ye,
Divorce ye from a woman of her beauty?
Of her integrity, her piety?
Her love to you, to all that honors ye,
Her chaste and virtuous love—are these fit causes?
What will you do to me when I have cloy'dweighed down; encumberedOED cloy v.6 ye?
You may find time out in eternity,
Deceit and violence in heavenly justice,
Life in the grave, and death among the blessed,
Ere stain or breach in her sweet reputation.
You have fooled enough, be wise now, and a woman.
You have shown a modesty sufficient,
If not too much for Court.
You have shown an impudence,
A more experienced bawd would blush and shake at;
You will make my kindred mighty.
Pray you hear me.
I do, Sir, and I count it a great offer.
Any of thine.
'Tis like enough you may clap honor on them,

But how 'twill sit,It is unclear in the copy-text whether this should read as “sit” or “fit.” Both words work in this context, and yield potentially different meanings. “Sit” suggests how Frederick’s adultery will occupy his internal character, while “fit” might allude to his reputation. Evanthe asks “how men will adore it” or what they will think of Frederick’s hypothetical decision to leave the Queen for Evanthe¬—how will such an act “fit” within public opinion of the King? and how men will adore it,
Is still the question. I'll tell you what they'll say, Sir,
What the report will be, and it will be true too,
And it must needs be comfort to your Master.
These are the issues of her impudence:
I'll tell your Grace, so dear I hold the Queen,
So dear that honor that she nursed me up in.
I would first take to me, for my lust, a moor,
One of your Gally-slaves, that cold and hunger,
Decrepit misery, had made a mock-manchimpanzee; unworthy of being called a manOED mock-man n.,
Than be your queen.
You are bravely resolute.
I had rather be a leper, and be shunned,
And die by pieces, rot into my grave,
Leaving no memory behind to know me,
Than be a high whore to eternity.
You have another suitor, I perceive by you,
You dare not slight me else.
I'll find him out,
Though he lie next thy heart hid, I'll discover him,
And ye proud pet, I'll make you curse your insolence.
Tongue of an angel, and the truth of Heaven,
How am I blessed?Exit Valerio
Podrano go in haste
To my sister's Gentlewoman, you know her well,
And bid her send her Mistress presently.

The lesser cabinetThe woman’s cabinet has been cited as proof of the role of “historical women[…]as[…]designated[…] poetic recipients,” as Diane Mitchell’s recent article “The Absent Lady and the Renaissance Lyric as Letter” (2019) clarifies (328). According to Mitchell, these cabinets “demonstrate that the ‘lady’ was, in fact, the ‘reader more often than we have recognized” (328). The letter from Valerio that the men eventually find is composed in verse form, supporting Mitchell’s argument for the prominence of the female poetry reader and recipient/audience in the early modern period. Furthermore, the significance of the cabinet receptacle was preservation-based, as the letters served “as visible, tactile evidence of the sender’s feelings” that “could be revisited again and again” (315). The lack of physical “evidence” in Frederick’s arduous courting of Evanthe is worth consideration as well here. Evanthe is concerned for her reputation and how Frederick will account for the esteem damage she will consequentially take as a young, outwardly chaste woman. Without hard proof of his love, Evanthe is left to her own word, which will likely not hold up against that of the King, should he violate his lofty and lust-driven verbal promises to her. SeeMitchell, Diane. "The Absent Lady and the Renaissance Lyric as Letter." ELR volume 49, number 3, 2019, pp. 304-29. she keeps her letters in,
And such like toyes, bring it to me instantly. Away.
I am gone.Exit Podrano.

div.stage: Enter the Queen with two Ladies.

lg.l: The Queen.
Let's quit the place, she may grow jealous.Exit Frederick and Sorano.
So suddenly departed, what's the reason?
Does my approach displease his Grace? Are my eyes
So hateful to him? Or my conversation
Infected, that he flies me? Fair Evanthe,
Are you there? Then I see his shame.
'Tis true, Madam,
It has pleased his Goodness to be pleasant with me.
'Tis strange to find thy modesty in this place.
Does the King offer fair? Does thy face take him?
Never blush, Evanthe, 'tis a very sweet one.
Does he rain gold, and precious promises
Into thy lap? Will he advance thy fortunes?
Shalt thou be mighty, wench?
Never mock, Madam;
'Tis rather on your part to be lamented,
At least revenged. I can be mighty, Lady,
And glorious, too—glorious and great as you are.
He will marry thee.
Who would not be a Queen, Madam?
'Tis true Evanthe, 'tis a brave ambition,
A golden dream, that may delude a good mind.
What shall become of me?
You must learn to pray;

Your age and honor will become a nunnery.To a modern reader, “nunnery” might simply suggest a convent or have religious implications, which makes great sense in this context, especially as Evanthe alludes to the Queen’s “age and honor” (i.e., as an aged woman who has already been married, the Queen’s only option would be to enter a religious convent to preserve such honor). However, another possible reading of “nunnery” as a “brothel” exists. OED nunnery n.1bThe OED’s slang entry on “nunnery” as “brothel” lists several literary examples, with Beaumont and Fletcher’s The Mad Lover from the 1647 folio being one of them. In this second reading of “nunnery,” Evanthe would also be suggesting that the Queen’s “age and honor” will be reduced to an “abandoned woman” or “prostitute." OED brothel n.2a“Nunnery” here additionally evokes Hamlet’s dismissive comment to Ophelia in Act 3, Scene 1: “Get thee to a nunnery.” In an entry in Oxford UP’s Notes and Queries, D.S. Bland cites one Professor Nevill Coghill who alludes to “some slender evidence” in the OED for the nunnery here referring to a brothel (332).
Wilt thou remember me?Weeps.
She weeps. Sweet Lady,
Upon my knees I ask your sacred pardon
For my rude boldness. And know, my sweet Mistress,
If ever there were ambition in Evanthe,
It was and is to do you faithful duties.
'Tis true I have been tempted by the King,
And with no few and potent charms, to wrong ye,
To violate the chaste joys of your bed,
And those not taking hold, to usurp your state.
But she that has been bred up under ye,
And daily fed upon your virtuous precepts,
Still growing strong by example of your goodness,
Having no errant motion from obedience,
Flies from these vanities as mere illusions.
And armed with honesty, defies all promises.
In token of this truth, I lay my life down
Under your sacred foot, to do you service.
Rise, my true friend, thou virtuous, bud of beauty.
Thou virgin's honor, sweetly blow and flourish,
And that rude nipping wind that seeks to blast thee,
Or taint thy root, be cursed to all posterity
To my protection from this hour I take ye,
Yes, and the King shall know—
Give his heat way, Madam,
And it will go out again. He may forget all.Exeunt.
What have we to do with the times? We cannot cure 'em. Let 'em go on—when they are swollen with surfetslack of moderation; excessive indulgence; excessOED surfeit n.5
They'll burst and stink, then all the world shall smell 'em.
A man may live a bawd, and be an honest man.
Yes, and a wise man too, 'tis a virtuous calling.
To his own wife especially, or to his sister.
The nearer to his own blood, still the more honest.
There want such honest men, would we had more of 'em.
To be a villain is no such rude matter.
No, if he be a neat one, and a perfect,
Art makes all excellent, what isn't gentle.
In a good cause to kill a dozen coxcombsfool; stupid personOED coxcomb n.4a?
That blunt rude fellows call good patriots?
Nothing, nor never looked after.
'Tis even as much, as easy too, as honest, & as clear,
To ravish matrons, and deflower coy wenches,
But here they are so willing, 'tis a compliment.
To pull down churches with pretention,
To build 'em fairer, may be done with honor,
And all this time believe no God.
I think so, 'tis faith enough if they name him in their angers,
Or on their rotten tombs engrave an angel.
Well, brave Alphonso, how happy had we been,
If thou had reigned?
Would I had his disease,
Tied like a leprosy to my posterity,
So he were right again.
What is his malady?
Nothing but sad and silent melancholy,
Laden with griefs and thoughts, no man knows why neither.
The good Brandino, father to the princess,
Used all the art and industry that might be
To free Alphonso from this dull calamity,
And seat him in his rule. He was his eldest,
And noblest too, had not fair nature stopped in him,
For which cause this was chosen to inherit
Frederick, the younger.
Does he use his brother
With that respect and honor that befits him?
He is kept privately(as they pretend)
To give more ease and comfort to his sickness.
But he has honest servants, the grave Rugio,
And Friar Marco, that wait upon his person,
And in a monastery he lives.
'Tis full of sadness
To see him when he comes to his father's tomb,
As once a day that is his pilgrimage.
While in devotion the choir sings an anthem,
How piously he kneels, and like a virgin
That some cross fate had cozenedcheatedOED cozen v.1a of her love,
Weeps 'till the stubborn marble sweats with pity.
And to his groans the whole choir bears a Chorus.

stage.corr: Enter Frederick and Sorano with the cabinet.

lg.l: So do I too. The King with his contrivers,
This is no place for us.Exit Camillo, Cleanthes, and Menallo.
This is a jewel.
Lay it aside, what paper's that?
A letter,
But 'tis a woman's, Sir, I know by the hand,
And the false authography—they write old Saxon.
May be her ghostly mother's, that instructs her.
No, 'tis a cousin', and came up with a great cake.
What's that?
A pair of gloves the Duchess gave her,
For so the outside says.
That other paper?
A charm for the toothache, here's nothing but Saints and crosses.
Look in that box, methinks that should hold secrets.
'Tis paint and curls of hair, she begins to exercise.
A glass of water too, I would fain taste it,
But I am wickedly afraid it will silence me,
Never a conduit pipe to convey this water.
These are all rings, deaths heads, and such mementoes
Her grandmother and worm-eaten aunts left to her,
To tell her what her beauty must arrive at.
That, that.
They are written songs, Sir, to provoke young ladies.
Lords, here's a prayer book, how these agree?
Here's a strange union.
Ever by a safest, you have a julip set to cool the patient.
Those, those.
They are verses to the blessed Evanthe.
Those may discover,
Read them out, Sorano.
Let those complain, that feels love's cruelty,
And in sad legends write their woes,
With roses gently has corrected me;
My war is without rage or blows;
My mistress' eyes shine fair on my desires,
And hope springs up inflam'd with her new fires.
No more an exile will I dwell,
With folded arms, and sighs all day,
Reckoning the torments of my hell,
And flinging my sweet joys away;
I am call'd home again to quiet peace,
My mistress smiles, and all my sorrows cease.
Yet what is living in her eyes?
Or being blessed with her sweet tongue,
If these no other joys imply?
A golden give, a pleasing wrong:
To be your own but one poor month, I'd give
My youth, my fortune, and then leave to live.
This is my rival, that I knew the hand now.
I know it, I have seen it, 'tis Valerio's,
That hopeful gentleman' that was brought up with ye,
And by your charge nourished and fed
At the same table, with the same allowance.
And all this courtesy to ruin me?
Cross my desires? Had better have fed humbler,
And stood at greater distance from my fury.
Go for him quickly, find him instantly,
While my impatient heart swells high with choller.
Better have loved despair, and safer kissed her.Exit Sorano and Podrano.
Thou old weak fool, dost thou know to what end,
To what betraying end he got this casket?
Dare thou deliver him without my ring?
Or a command from mine own mouth? that cabinet
That holds my heart, you inconsiderate ass,
Thou brainlessidiot.
I saw you go with him,
At their first word commit your person to him,
And made no scruple. He is your brother's gentleman,
And for any thing I know, an honest man.
And might not I upon the same security deliver him a box?
A bottleheadidiot; fool; blockheadOED bottle-head n.2.
You shall have cause to chafe, as I will handle it.
I had rather thou had delivered me to pirates,
Betrayed me to uncurable diseases,
Hung up my picture in a marketplace,
And sold me to wild bawds.
As I take it, Madam,
Your maidenheadvirginity; hymenOED maidenhead n.1a lies not in that cabinet;
You have a closet, and you keep the key too,
Why are you vexed thus?
I could curse thee wickedly,
And wish thee more deformed than age can make thee:
Perpetual hunger, and no teeth to satisfy it,
Weight on thee still, nor sleep be found to ease it.
Those hands that gave the casket, may the palsy
Forever make unuseful, even to feed thee.
Long winters, that thy bones may turn to icicles
No Hell can thaw again, inhabit by thee.
Is thy care like thy body, all on crookedness?
How scurvily thou criest now? Like a drunkard,
I'll have as pure tears from a dirty spout.
Do, swear thou didst this ignorantly, swear it,
Swear and be damned, thou half witch.
These are fine words, well Madam, Madam.
'Tis not well thou mummy,
'Tis impudently, basely done, thou dirty—
Has your young sanctity done railing, Madam,
Against your innocent squire? Do you see this sonnet?
This loving script? Do you know from where it came too?
I do, and dare avouch it pure and honest.
You have private visitors, my noble lady,
That in sweet numbers court your goodly virtues,
And to the height of adoration.
Well Sir,
There's neither heresy nor treason in it.
A prince may beg at the door while these feast with ye.
A favor or a grace, from such as I am.
Course, common things. You are welcome; pray come near, Sir.
Do you know this paper?
I am betrayed! I do, Sir,
'Tis mine, my hand and heart, if I dieachieve sexual orgasmOED die v.7d for her,
I am her martyr—love and time shall honor me.
You saucy Sir, that came in my Lady's name,
For her guilt cabinet, you cheating Sir too,
You scurvy Usher, with as scurvy legs,
And a worse face, thou poor base hanging holder,
How dare thou come to me with a lie in your mouth?
An impudent lie?
Hollow, good Jill, you hobble.
A stinking lie, more stinking than the teller,
To play the pilfering knavedishonest, unprincipled manOED knave n.3a, there have been rascals
Brought up to fetch and carry like your worship,
That have been hanged for less, whipped there are daily.
And if the Law will do me right—
What then, old maggot?
Thy mother was cartedcarried away unceremoniouslyOED cart v.1e younger; I'll have thy hide,
Thy mangy hide, embroidered with a dog-whip,
As it is now with potent pox, and thicker.
Peace, good antiquity, I'll have your bones else
Ground into gunpowder to shoot at cats with.
One word more, and I'll blanch thee like an almond,
There's no such cure for the she-falling-sickness,
As the powder of a dried bawd's skin, be silent,
You are very prodigal of your service here, Sir,
Of your life more it seems.
I repent neither,
Because Your Grace shall understand it comes
From the best part of love, my pure affection,
And kindled with chaste flame, I will not fly from it,
If it be error to desire to marry,
And marry her that sanctity would dote on,
I have done amiss; if it be a treason
To graft my soul to virtue, and to grow there,
To love the tree that bears such happiness;
Conceive me, Sir, this fruit was never forbidden;
No, to desire to taste too, I am traitor.
Had you but plants enough of this blessed tree, Sir,
Set round about your Court to beautify it,
Deaths twice so many, to dismay the aproachers,
The ground would scarce yield graves to noble lovers.
'Tis well maintained; you wish and pray to fortune,
Here in your sonnet, and she has heard your prayers,
So much you dote upon your own undoing.
But one month to enjoy her as your wife,
Though at the expiring of that time you die for't.
I could wish many, many ages, Sir,
To grow as old as time in her embraces,
If Heaven would grant it, and you smile upon it.
But if my choice were two hours, and then perish,
I would not pull my heart back.
You have your wish,
Tomorrow I will see you nobly married,
Your month take out in all content and pleasure.
The first day of the following month you die for it .
Kneel not,, not all your prayers can divert me.
Now mark your sentence, mark it, scornful Lady,
If when Valerio's dead, within twelve hours,
For there's your latest time, you find not out
Another husband on the same condition
To marry you again, you die yourself too.
Now you are merciful, I thank your Grace.
If when you are married, you but seek to escape
Out of the Kingdom, you, or she, or both,
Or to infect men's minds with hot commotions,
You die both instantly—will you love me now, Lady?
My tale will now be heard, but now I scorn ye. Exeunt..
Is our fair love, our honest, our entire,
Come to this hazard?
'Tis a noble one, and I am much in love with malice for it,
Envy could not have studied me away,
Nor fortune pointed out a path to honor,
Straighter and nobler, if she had her eyes.
When I have once enjoyed my sweet Evanthe,
And blessed my youth with her most dear embraces,
I have done my journey here, my day is out,
All that the world has else is foolery,
Labor, and loss of time—what should I live for?
Think but man's life a month, and we are happy.
I would not have my joys grow old for anything.
A paradise, as thou art my Evanthe,
Is only made to wonder at a little,
Enough for human eyes, and then to wander from.
Come, do not weep, sweet, you dishonor me.
Your tears and griefs but question my ability,
Whether I dare die: Do you love entirely?
You know I do.
Then grudge not my felicity.
I'll to the Queen.
Do anything that's honest,
But if you suepursue to him in death, I hate you.
